text: This message was given to Amos, a shepherd from the town of Tekoa in Judah. He received this message in visions two years before the earthquake, when Uzziah was king of Judah and Jeroboam II, the son of Jehoash, was king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what he saw and heard:
“The Lord’s voice will roar from Zion
    and thunder from Jerusalem!
The lush pastures of the shepherds will dry up;
    the grass on Mount Carmel will wither and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
“The people of Damascus have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They beat down my people in Gilead
    as grain is threshed with iron sledges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on King Hazael’s palace,
    and the fortresses of King Ben-hadad will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will break down the gates of Damascus
    and slaughter the people in the valley of Aven.
I will destroy the ruler in Beth-eden,
    and the people of Aram will go as captives to Kir,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“The people of Gaza have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They sent whole villages into exile,
    selling them as slaves to Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on the walls of Gaza,
    and all its fortresses will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will slaughter the people of Ashdod
    and destroy the king of Ashkelon.
Then I will turn to attack Ekron,
    and the few Philistines still left will be killed,”
    says the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“The people of Tyre have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They broke their treaty of brotherhood with Israel,
    selling whole villages as slaves to Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on the walls of Tyre,
    and all its fortresses will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“The people of Edom have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They chased down their relatives, the Israelites, with swords,
    showing them no mercy.
In their rage, they slashed them continually
    and were unrelenting in their anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on Teman,
    and the fortresses of Bozrah will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
“The people of Ammon have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
When they attacked Gilead to extend their borders,
    they ripped open pregnant women with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on the walls of Rabbah,
    and all its fortresses will be destroyed.
The battle will come upon them with shouts,
    like a whirlwind in a mighty storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And their king and his princes will go into exile together,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
“The people of Moab have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They desecrated the bones of Edom’s king,
    burning them to ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on the land of Moab,
    and all the fortresses in Kerioth will be destroyed.
The people will fall in the noise of battle,
    as the warriors shout and the ram’s horn sounds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will destroy their king
    and slaughter all their princes,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
“The people of Judah have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They have rejected the instruction of the Lord,
    refusing to obey his decrees.
They have been led astray by the same lies
    that deceived their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will send down fire on Judah,
    and all the fortresses of Jerusalem will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“The people of Israel have sinned again and again,
    and I will not let them go unpunished!
They sell honorable people for silver
    and poor people for a pair of sandals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They trample helpless people in the dust
    and shove the oppressed out of the way.
Both father and son sleep with the same woman,
    corrupting my holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At their religious festivals,
    they lounge in clothing their debtors put up as security.
In the house of their gods,
    they drink wine bought with unjust fines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But as my people watched,
    I destroyed the Amorites,
though they were as tall as cedars
    and as strong as oaks.
I destroyed the fruit on their branches
    and dug out their roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It was I who rescued you from Egypt
    and led you through the desert for forty years,
    so you could possess the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I chose some of your sons to be prophets
    and others to be Nazirites.
Can you deny this, my people of Israel?”
    asks the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you caused the Nazirites to sin by making them drink wine,
    and you commanded the prophets, ‘Shut up!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So I will make you groan
    like a wagon loaded down with sheaves of grain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your fastest runners will not get away.
    The strongest among you will become weak.
Even mighty warriors will be unable to save themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The archers will not stand their ground.
The swiftest runners won’t be fast enough to escape.
    Even those riding horses won’t be able to save themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On that day the most courageous of your fighting men
    will drop their weapons and run for their lives,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to this message that the Lord has spoken against you, O people of Israel—against the entire family I rescued from Egypt:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From among all the families on the earth,
    I have been intimate with you alone.
That is why I must punish you
    for all your sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can two people walk together
    without agreeing on the direction?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does a lion ever roar in a thicket
    without first finding a victim?
Does a young lion growl in its den
    without first catching its prey?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does a bird ever get caught in a trap
    that has no bait?
Does a trap spring shut
    when there’s nothing to catch?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the ram’s horn blows a warning,
    shouldn’t the people be alarmed?
Does disaster come to a city
    unless the Lord has planned it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the Sovereign Lord never does anything
    until he reveals his plans to his servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lion has roared—
    so who isn’t frightened?
The Sovereign Lord has spoken—
    so who can refuse to proclaim his message?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Announce this to the leaders of Philistia
    and to the great ones of Egypt:
“Take your seats now on the hills around Samaria,
    and witness the chaos and oppression in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My people have forgotten how to do right,”
    says the Lord.
“Their fortresses are filled with wealth
    taken by theft and violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore,” says the Sovereign Lord,
    “an enemy is coming!
He will surround them and shatter their defenses.
    Then he will plunder all their fortresses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is what the Lord says:
“A shepherd who tries to rescue a sheep from a lion’s mouth
    will recover only two legs or a piece of an ear.
So it will be for the Israelites in Samaria lying on luxurious beds,
    and for the people of Damascus reclining on couches.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now listen to this, and announce it throughout all Israel,” says the Lord, the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“On the very day I punish Israel for its sins,
    I will destroy the pagan altars at Bethel.
The horns of the altar will be cut off
    and fall to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will destroy the beautiful homes of the wealthy—
    their winter mansions and their summer houses, too—
all their palaces filled with ivory,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to me, you fat cows
    living in Samaria,
you women who oppress the poor
    and crush the needy,
and who are always calling to your husbands,
    “Bring us another drink!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Sovereign Lord has sworn this by his holiness:
“The time will come when you will be led away
    with hooks in your noses.
Every last one of you will be dragged away
    like a fish on a hook!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Go ahead and offer sacrifices to the idols at Bethel.
    Keep on disobeying at Gilgal.
Offer sacrifices each morning,
    and bring your tithes every three days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Present your bread made with yeast
    as an offering of thanksgiving.
Then give your extra voluntary offerings
    so you can brag about it everywhere!
This is the kind of thing you Israelites love to do,”
    says the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I brought hunger to every city
    and famine to every town.
But still you would not return to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I kept the rain from falling
    when your crops needed it the most.
I sent rain on one town
    but withheld it from another.
Rain fell on one field,
    while another field withered away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People staggered from town to town looking for water,
    but there was never enough.
But still you would not return to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I struck your farms and vineyards with blight and mildew.
    Locusts devoured all your fig and olive trees.
But still you would not return to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I sent plagues on you
    like the plagues I sent on Egypt long ago.
I killed your young men in war
    and led all your horses away.
    The stench of death filled the air!
But still you would not return to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I destroyed some of your cities,
    as I destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
Those of you who survived
    were like charred sticks pulled from a fire.
But still you would not return to me,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore, I will bring upon you all the disasters I have announced.
    Prepare to meet your God in judgment, you people of Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord is the one who shaped the mountains,
    stirs up the winds, and reveals his thoughts to mankind.
He turns the light of dawn into darkness
    and treads on the heights of the earth.
    The Lord God of Heaven’s Armies is his name!
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, you people of Israel! Listen to this funeral song I am singing:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The virgin Israel has fallen,
    never to rise again!
She lies abandoned on the ground,
    with no one to help her up.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Sovereign Lord says:
“When a city sends a thousand men to battle,
    only a hundred will return.
When a town sends a hundred,
    only ten will come back alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now this is what the Lord says to the family of Israel:
“Come back to me and live!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t worship at the pagan altars at Bethel;
    don’t go to the shrines at Gilgal or Beersheba.
For the people of Gilgal will be dragged off into exile,
    and the people of Bethel will be reduced to nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come back to the Lord and live!
Otherwise, he will roar through Israel like a fire,
    devouring you completely.
Your gods in Bethel
    won’t be able to quench the flames.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You twist justice, making it a bitter pill for the oppressed.
    You treat the righteous like dirt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the Lord who created the stars,
    the Pleiades and Orion.
He turns darkness into morning
    and day into night.
He draws up water from the oceans
    and pours it down as rain on the land.
    The Lord is his name!
speaker: Narrator

text:
With blinding speed and power he destroys the strong,
    crushing all their defenses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How you hate honest judges!
    How you despise people who tell the truth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You trample the poor,
    stealing their grain through taxes and unfair rent.
Therefore, though you build beautiful stone houses,
    you will never live in them.
Though you plant lush vineyards,
    you will never drink wine from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know the vast number of your sins
    and the depth of your rebellions.
You oppress good people by taking bribes
    and deprive the poor of justice in the courts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So those who are smart keep their mouths shut,
    for it is an evil time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do what is good and run from evil
    so that you may live!
Then the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies will be your helper,
    just as you have claimed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hate evil and love what is good;
    turn your courts into true halls of justice.
Perhaps even yet the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies
    will have mercy on the remnant of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, this is what the Lord, the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, says:
“There will be crying in all the public squares
    and mourning in every street.
Call for the farmers to weep with you,
    and summon professional mourners to wail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There will be wailing in every vineyard,
    for I will destroy them all,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What sorrow awaits you who say,
    “If only the day of the Lord were here!”
You have no idea what you are wishing for.
    That day will bring darkness, not light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day you will be like a man who runs from a lion—
    only to meet a bear.
Escaping from the bear, he leans his hand against a wall in his house—
    and he’s bitten by a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the day of the Lord will be dark and hopeless,
    without a ray of joy or hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I hate all your show and pretense—
    the hypocrisy of your religious festivals and solemn assemblies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not accept your burnt offerings and grain offerings.
    I won’t even notice all your choice peace offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Away with your noisy hymns of praise!
    I will not listen to the music of your harps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Instead, I want to see a mighty flood of justice,
    an endless river of righteous living.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Was it to me you were bringing sacrifices and offerings during the forty years in the wilderness, Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: No, you served your pagan gods—Sakkuth your king god and Kaiwan your star god—the images you made for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will send you into exile, to a land east of Damascus,” says the Lord, whose name is the God of Heaven’s Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What sorrow awaits you who lounge in luxury in Jerusalem,
    and you who feel secure in Samaria!
You are famous and popular in Israel,
    and people go to you for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But go over to Calneh
    and see what happened there.
Then go to the great city of Hamath
    and down to the Philistine city of Gath.
You are no better than they were,
    and look at how they were destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You push away every thought of coming disaster,
    but your actions only bring the day of judgment closer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How terrible for you who sprawl on ivory beds
    and lounge on your couches,
eating the meat of tender lambs from the flock
    and of choice calves fattened in the stall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You sing trivial songs to the sound of the harp
    and fancy yourselves to be great musicians like David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You drink wine by the bowlful
    and perfume yourselves with fragrant lotions.
    You care nothing about the ruin of your nation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, you will be the first to be led away as captives.
    Suddenly, all your parties will end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Sovereign Lord has sworn by his own name, and this is what he, the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, says: 
“I despise the arrogance of Israel,
    and I hate their fortresses.
I will give this city
    and everything in it to their enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (If there are ten men left in one house, they will all die.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when a relative who is responsible to dispose of the dead goes into the house to carry out the bodies, he will ask the last survivor, “Is anyone else with you?” When the person begins to swear, “No, by . . . ,” he will interrupt and say, “Stop! Don’t even mention the name of the Lord.”)
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord gives the command,
    homes both great and small will be smashed to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can horses gallop over boulders?
    Can oxen be used to plow them?
But that’s how foolish you are when you turn justice into poison
    and the sweet fruit of righteousness into bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you brag about your conquest of Lo-debar.
    You boast, “Didn’t we take Karnaim by our own strength?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O people of Israel, I am about to bring an enemy nation against you,”
    says the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies.
“They will oppress you throughout your land—
    from Lebo-hamath in the north
    to the Arabah Valley in the south.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Sovereign Lord showed me a vision. I saw him preparing to send a vast swarm of locusts over the land. This was after the king’s share had been harvested from the fields and as the main crop was coming up.
speaker: Narrator

text: In my vision the locusts ate every green plant in sight. Then I said, “O Sovereign Lord, please forgive us or we will not survive, for Israel is so small.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord relented from this plan. “I will not do it,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Sovereign Lord showed me another vision. I saw him preparing to punish his people with a great fire. The fire had burned up the depths of the sea and was devouring the entire land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “O Sovereign Lord, please stop or we will not survive, for Israel is so small.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord relented from this plan, too. “I will not do that either,” said the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he showed me another vision. I saw the Lord standing beside a wall that had been built using a plumb line. He was using a plumb line to see if it was still straight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said to me, “Amos, what do you see?”
I answered, “A plumb line.”
And the Lord replied, “I will test my people with this plumb line. I will no longer ignore all their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pagan shrines of your ancestors will be ruined, and the temples of Israel will be destroyed; I will bring the dynasty of King Jeroboam to a sudden end.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amaziah, the priest of Bethel, sent a message to Jeroboam, king of Israel: “Amos is hatching a plot against you right here on your very doorstep! What he is saying is intolerable.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is saying, ‘Jeroboam will soon be killed, and the people of Israel will be sent away into exile.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amaziah sent orders to Amos: “Get out of here, you prophet! Go on back to the land of Judah, and earn your living by prophesying there!
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t bother us with your prophecies here in Bethel. This is the king’s sanctuary and the national place of worship!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amos replied, “I’m not a professional prophet, and I was never trained to be one. I’m just a shepherd, and I take care of sycamore-fig trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord called me away from my flock and told me, ‘Go and prophesy to my people in Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now then, listen to this message from the Lord:
“You say,
‘Don’t prophesy against Israel.
    Stop preaching against my people.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But this is what the Lord says:
‘Your wife will become a prostitute in this city,
    and your sons and daughters will be killed.
Your land will be divided up,
    and you yourself will die in a foreign land.
And the people of Israel will certainly become captives in exile,
    far from their homeland.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Sovereign Lord showed me another vision. In it I saw a basket filled with ripe fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do you see, Amos?” he asked.
I replied, “A basket full of ripe fruit.”
Then the Lord said, “Like this fruit, Israel is ripe for punishment! I will not delay their punishment again.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the singing in the temple will turn to wailing. Dead bodies will be scattered everywhere. They will be carried out of the city in silence. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to this, you who rob the poor
    and trample down the needy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You can’t wait for the Sabbath day to be over
    and the religious festivals to end
    so you can get back to cheating the helpless.
You measure out grain with dishonest measures
    and cheat the buyer with dishonest scales.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you mix the grain you sell
    with chaff swept from the floor.
Then you enslave poor people
    for one piece of silver or a pair of sandals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the Lord has sworn this oath
    by his own name, the Pride of Israel:
“I will never forget
    the wicked things you have done!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth will tremble for your deeds,
    and everyone will mourn.
The ground will rise like the Nile River at floodtime;
    it will heave up, then sink again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In that day,” says the Sovereign Lord,
“I will make the sun go down at noon
    and darken the earth while it is still day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will turn your celebrations into times of mourning
    and your singing into weeping.
You will wear funeral clothes
    and shave your heads to show your sorrow—
as if your only son had died.
    How very bitter that day will be!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The time is surely coming,” says the Sovereign Lord,
    “when I will send a famine on the land—
not a famine of bread or water
    but of hearing the words of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will stagger from sea to sea
    and wander from border to border
searching for the word of the Lord,
    but they will not find it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beautiful girls and strong young men
    will grow faint in that day,
    thirsting for the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And those who swear by the shameful idols of Samaria—
    who take oaths in the name of the god of Dan
    and make vows in the name of the god of Beersheba—
they will all fall down,
    never to rise again.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I saw a vision of the Lord standing beside the altar. He said,
“Strike the tops of the Temple columns,
    so that the foundation will shake.
Bring down the roof
    on the heads of the people below.
I will kill with the sword those who survive.
    No one will escape!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Even if they dig down to the place of the dead,
    I will reach down and pull them up.
Even if they climb up into the heavens,
    I will bring them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if they hide at the very top of Mount Carmel,
    I will search them out and capture them.
Even if they hide at the bottom of the ocean,
    I will send the sea serpent after them to bite them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if their enemies drive them into exile,
    I will command the sword to kill them there.
I am determined to bring disaster upon them
    and not to help them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
    touches the land and it melts,
    and all its people mourn.
The ground rises like the Nile River at floodtime,
    and then it sinks again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s home reaches up to the heavens,
    while its foundation is on the earth.
He draws up water from the oceans
    and pours it down as rain on the land.
    The Lord is his name!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Are you Israelites more important to me
    than the Ethiopians?” asks the Lord.
“I brought Israel out of Egypt,
    but I also brought the Philistines from Crete
    and led the Arameans out of Kir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I, the Sovereign Lord,
    am watching this sinful nation of Israel.
I will destroy it
    from the face of the earth.
But I will never completely destroy the family of Israel,”
    says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For I will give the command
    and will shake Israel along with the other nations
as grain is shaken in a sieve,
    yet not one true kernel will be lost.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But all the sinners will die by the sword—
    all those who say, ‘Nothing bad will happen to us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In that day I will restore the fallen house of David.
    I will repair its damaged walls.
From the ruins I will rebuild it
    and restore its former glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Israel will possess what is left of Edom
    and all the nations I have called to be mine.”
The Lord has spoken,
    and he will do these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The time will come,” says the Lord,
“when the grain and grapes will grow faster
    than they can be harvested.
Then the terraced vineyards on the hills of Israel
    will drip with sweet wine!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring my exiled people of Israel
    back from distant lands,
and they will rebuild their ruined cities
    and live in them again.
They will plant vineyards and gardens;
    they will eat their crops and drink their wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will firmly plant them there
    in their own land.
They will never again be uprooted
    from the land I have given them,”
    says the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator
